translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha.
The Great Worthy
The Wise Sayings
I am a great worthy, a Sakyan,
The sage, craving, the hindrances;
Liberated, liberated, well-seen,
I pay homage to the supreme, excellent enlightenment.
By the sage, by the sage's son,
The wicked are defeated, gone forth;
As is the false Dhamma-
The ancient ones, the ancient ones, and so on.
Thus the Tathāgata's teachings,
Following worldly conduct;
By what means the wise
Should conquer those who act for their own gain.
Herein is the essence of beings,
Friends, teachers, and those who drink;
The one with good conduct, good understanding, and self-control,
The learned one, the one who gives meaning.
Having made the poet the king,
The thread, the needle, and the gold;
Making the ornament beginning with the letter ga,
Delightful here.
The one with clear knowledge,
The one known for his meaning, not;
The reflection of the bright light,
Does not see the shadow of the crocodile.
Even the one with great splendor, the splendor,
Makes the clay soft;
The water makes the soft,
The good speech and the harsh.
The soft conquers the hard,
The soft conquers the strong;
There is nothing that the soft does not conquer,
For the soft conquers all.
The sandal-wood is cool in the world,🔽But the moon is cooler than that;
From the sandal-wood and the moon,

analyzed: vākyam sādhu su bhāsitam  patta kalla uditam appam
translated: A well-spoken word is cooler.🔽A little well-spoken word
Is better than a lot of words;
Even a little salt is tasty,

analyzed: suttam sādurasaḥ siyā  satthakā api bahu vācā
translated: If it is mixed with rice.🔽There are many who speak much,

analyzed: na ādarāḥ bahu bhāṇinaḥ  sa upakāram udāsīnam
translated: But few who speak what is dear;🔽The river water is seen to be cool,
But it is not helpful to the thirsty.
For the tree of the round of rebirths,

analyzed: dvayam eva a matam phalam  subhāsita ssa sārādaḥ
translated: There are only two fruits that are deathless;🔽The fruit of a well-spoken word,
And the company of the virtuous.
A stone umbrella is heavy,
But the gods’ umbrella is heavier;
The advice of the elders is heavier,
But the Buddha’s advice is heavier.
A scale is light in the world,
But a fickle person is lighter;
A person who speaks too much is lighter,
But one who is negligent in the Dhamma is lightest.🔽Life for beings in this world
Is passing away as it goes;
Therefore, do not be negligent,
Go to the Jina’s Dispensation.
The wise man is praised by the wise,

analyzed: daṇḍaḥ bālena dīyate  paṇḍitaḥ paṇḍitena iva
translated: and is given by the wise;🔽The wise man is praised by the wise,
and is praised by the wise.
Among a hundred, a hero is born,
and among a thousand, a wise man;
Among a hundred thousand, it is said,
a giver is born.
The wise man and the king,
are never equal;
The king is worshipped by his equals,
the Buddha is worshipped by all.
The burden of the strong,
the axe of the woodcutter;
The expert of the learned,

analyzed: koparaḥ piya vādinam  nanu te yevasantā no
translated: the copper of the sweet-speakers.
Are not the oceans and the Nāga mountains🔽the same as before?
Those who do not keep even a little
boundary, even in the world-destruction.
The oceans are not able to transgress
the boundary that is kept.🔽The good do not want to transgress
the boundary, even if they are able to.
The hundred long-lived gods,
the cause of happiness for all beings;🔽And the hundred unrighteous,
the cause of suffering for all, without doubt.
When there are excellent good people,
all good people;
When there is one fragrant tree,
all fragrant trees.
If one person, by himself,
could defeat a great multitude,
then all would go to defeat,
who would not be destroyed by the wise?
The body and its qualities
are far apart, there is a great difference between them.
The body is destroyed in a moment,
but the qualities remain standing.
If one who is pure and spotless

analyzed: nimalam mala vāhinā  yaḥ saḥ kāyena labhetha
translated: is carried off by one who is dirty and stained,🔽what is it that he has gained

analyzed: kim na laddham bhave nu kim
translated: by what he has gained?
For those who desire the good of the Dhamma,

analyzed: pāṇam saṃsiddhi kāraṇam  tad nighātā kinnahatam
translated: the life of a human being is the cause of success.🔽What is not destroyed by the destruction of that?
What is protected by the protection of that?🔽The self is the kinsman of a human being,

analyzed: ripu attāva jantunaṃ  attā ava niyataḥ ñāti
translated: the self is the enemy of a living being.🔽The self is the relative that is certain,

analyzed: attā ava niyataḥ ripu  attana uparicāgena
translated: the self is the enemy that is certain.🔽The protection of what is cherished
by the self’s own conduct,
is done only by the good,
that is not considered good policy.
Grass, earth, and water,

analyzed: catutthī vākya suṭṭhu tā  etāni hi sataṃgehe  na ucchindante kadācipi
translated: and the fourth, purity of speech,🔽these are never cut off🔽in the house of a good man.
The rivers drink the water,
the tree eats the fruit,
the cloud never eats the crop,
For the sake of others, a hundred times.
A hundred times, with harsh words,
The mind does not go to the other side;
Just as it is not possible with a blade of grass,
To heat the water in the ocean.
The mind that has attained greatness,
Becomes soft like a lotus;
And the mind that has fallen away from greatness,
Is like a stone in a heap of rocks.
Having attained great wealth,
Knowledge and prosperity as well;
One should live with humility,

analyzed: paṇḍito so pavuccati  na ālabbham abhipatthenti
translated: That wise one is called a sage.🔽They do not obtain what they desire,

analyzed: naṭṭham pi na ca saḥ care
translated: And they do not grieve over what is lost;

The wise one should not despise;🔽What is the difference between a bamboo pole
And the sun that illuminates the ocean?
By one alone, both qualities and faults,
There is no one who is free from;
For the fine thread of the lotus,

translated: The husk becomes a stone.🔽Bearing the great weapons,🔽The learned ones;
The cutters of doubts,
Tired by greed and delusion.
Even seeing faults in the virtuous,
The one who speaks with praise of qualities;
Even though the world exists,

analyzed: cande passati lañchanam  nipuṇe sutam eseyya

analyzed: dūrepi vasatam satam  ketake gandha ghāsāya

translated: The wise one, endowed with learning,🔽Is called “one who knows where there is benefit.”🔽One who seeks good should go

translated: But one should not apply all.

And all the time one is found in the water.

analyzed: vasum gaṇhanti dūraṭṭhā  pabbate ratana ucite
translated: The precious gems are taken from afar,🔽From the mountain where gems are found.

analyzed: evam bālāḥ bahussute  hiraññena migānam iva
translated: So it is with fools and the learned.🔽Even one of good conduct is like an animal
To one of bad conduct.
What is the use of the learning of fools,🔽If it is unrighteous and not in accordance with the Dhamma?
What is the use of the learning of a wicked man,
If it is not in his heart?
What is the use of the honey in the hollow of a tree,
If it is not sweet?
Even a wise man, if he is foolish,
Will not make friends with a wise man,
If he does not see his own benefit and the benefit of others,

original: Nibbānantaṃ sukhaṃ labhe.🔽Haṃso majjhe nakākānaṃ,🔽Sīho gunnaṃ nasobhati;
analyzed: sukham labhe  haṃsaḥ majjhe nakākānam  sīhaḥ gunnam nasobhati
translated: And if he does not attain the happiness of Nibbāna.🔽A swan does not shine among the geese,🔽A lion does not shine among the deer,
A horse does not shine among the horses of the Gadrabhas,
And a wise man does not shine among fools.
Even if he is surrounded by the unrighteous,
He is good if he is not associated with them.
If he is associated with many,
He should go to a place where there is no one.

analyzed: nadī tire khate kūpe  araṇī tālavaṇṭake
translated: On the bank of a river, in a pit,🔽In a place where there is no fire, in a place where there is no salt,

translated: They are like a lute that is not played.🔽If a wise man is not asked,🔽He is like a drum that is not beaten;

An ornament with perfect qualities,

analyzed: phala anisaṃsaḥ bhāva iti  vahantaḥ porissaṃdhuram  atisītam ati uṇham
translated: The fruit is the cause of development,🔽Carrying the yoke for a good person.🔽Too cold, too hot,

Doing a man’s duties,

Seeking fame and gain,

Seeks his own path.🔽Lions, good people, and elephants go

There itself they die,
Crows, bad people, and deer.
In whom there is no right or wrong,
No drinking, no relatives;
No one has come to us with news of him,
He does not live in this country.
The rich, the astrologer, the king,
The river, the doctor, these people:
Where these five are not found,
He does not live in that country.
The fear of the fearless,
The fear of death for the dead,
The highest fear for all,
Is the greatest fear of contempt.

analyzed: a mānanā yattha siyā  santānam avamānanā
translated: Where there is disrespect,🔽And contempt for the good,

analyzed: avisesa karena kaḥ  dukkhaḥ nivāsaḥ sambādhe

analyzed: aṅgam dhanam jivitam ca api sabbam
translated: For the sake of all, one should give up wealth and life,

the hand with bracelets,

The Discussion of Division
The time of the wise passes with the discussion of the scriptures,
with the misfortune of the wicked,
with sleep and quarrels.🔽Thousands of occasions for sorrow,
hundreds of occasions for fear,
daily beset the fool,
but not the wise man.🔽The fool is too long in being born,
the medium one is clever;
having placed Vāsudeva in the forefront,
all the demons are deceitful.
The fool does not shine in the world,
The one who is praised as the best,
Even if he falls into a pit,
The one who has mastered the arts shines forth.
The sword, which is the weapon for subduing the wicked,
Makes the wicked intoxicated;
The fire of the eye-formations
Is like a water-wheel for owls.
Even a slight good deed
For the good remains like a drawing in stone;
Like a drawing in water for the wicked,
What is done perishes.🔽Even a little good deed
For the good is like a well in a desert;
Even much for the wicked
Is like water in the ocean.
If one has an angry mind,
Anger is like a drawing in stone;
For a good person who should be angry,
The drawing in water remains for a long time.

analyzed: bālassa jīvitam pāpam  mitarassi taram bhave
translated: The life of a fool is evil,🔽Like a thief in the world;
Like a king to the people,

The lion is strong with prey,
The porcupine is stronger than that,
The king is stronger than men,
The magician is strongest of all.
The king is the best of the people,
The greedy person is the worst;
Even for these who desire much,
The impermanence of desire is great.
The sleepy, the discontented,🔽The ungrateful, the fearful,
Are never able to learn
The conduct that is good.
The sleepy, the lustful,
The happy, the lazy rich man,
The one who is always wanting, the one who loves his work,

Wealth is the greatest friend in the world.

analyzed: na rūpinī na paññāṇo  nakulīnaḥ u padhāna tā
translated: Not one’s beauty, not one’s wisdom,🔽Not one’s noble birth, nor one’s deeds,🔽But the possession of wealth alone
Makes a man distinguished when misfortune comes.

original: Kalyāṇamittaṃ kantāraṃ,🔽Yuddhaṃ sabhāyaṃ bhāsituṃ;🔽Asatthā gantu micchanti,🔽Muḷhā tecaturojanā.🔽Ahitā paṭisedhoca,🔽Hitesuca payojanaṃ;
analyzed: kalyāṇa mittam kantāram  yuddham sabhāyam bhāsitum  asatthāḥ gantu micchanti  muḷhā te catur ojanā  ahitā  hitesu ca payojanam
translated: A good friend in the wilderness,

original: Byasanesva pariccāgo,🔽Saṅkhepā mittalakkhaṇaṃ.🔽Āture byasanepatte,🔽Dubbhikkhe sattu viggahe;
analyzed: byasanesu pariccāgaḥ  saṅkhepāḥ mitta lakkhaṇam  āture byasane patte  dubbhikkhe sattu viggahe
translated: A good friend in war, a good friend in court,

original: Rājadvāre susāneca,🔽Yo tiṭṭhati sabandhavo.🔽So bandhu yo hiteyutto,🔽So pitā yo tu posako;
analyzed: rājadvāre susāne ca  yaḥ tiṭṭhati sabandhavaḥ  saḥ bandhu yaḥ hiteyuttaḥ  saḥ pitā yaḥ tu posakaḥ
translated: A good friend in the king’s palace,🔽A good friend in the cemetery—🔽He is a friend who helps in need,🔽He is a father who supports and nourishes,
He is a kinsman in whom one can confide,
She is a wife who is faithful.
One who is helpful, one who is a good friend,

analyzed: viññūca dullabhā janā  yathā u sadham ca sādum ca
translated: One who is wise—such people are hard to find;🔽As a rule, people are like salt and sugar,
Or like medicine when one is sick.
One who is not arrogant, one who is not lazy,

analyzed: a saṭṭhaḥ u ca sacca vā suci
translated: He is not deceitful, but truthful and pure;
He is not greedy, but desires what is right;
Such is the most dear friend.
He who, having abandoned the permanent,🔽Associates with the impermanent,
Even the permanent will be lost to him,
In the impermanent there is no opportunity for discussion.
The greedy one should be taken by the object of his greed,🔽The stubborn one by the work of the bowl,
The deluded one by following his desires,
The wise one by what is as it really is.
The superior one by the hand,🔽The hero by the victory of division,
The inferior one by the foot,
The equal one by the leap.
By whatever is the strength of that one,
By that very thing that man,
The wise one, having approached,
Quickly leads him under his control.
By whom he desires to make a connection,
By that he should make three signs:
Disagreement, connection of meaning,

analyzed: parokkhe dāra dassanam  acca abhikkhaṇa saṃsaggā
translated: Seeing the wife of another.🔽By excessive intimacy,
And by not running away,
By this friends are destroyed,
And by begging at the wrong time.
Therefore one should not go excessively,
Nor go too often or too rarely;
In time one should beg when one should beg,
Thus friends are not destroyed.
They are equal to or better than this,
Their bond does not grow old.
He who can bear what is intended,
And he who knows the teaching.
If they argue while calm,
They quickly reconcile again.
Fools break up as soon as they are struck,
They do not reach the middle of reconciliation.
With what friendship one’s security is lost,
Even before it is destroyed,🔽The wise one should guard it,

analyzed: rakkhe akkhiva paṇḍitaḥ  yenamittena saṃsaggā  yogakkhemaḥ pavaḍḍhati
translated: As if it were his own eye.🔽With what friendship one’s security increases,
The wise one should act in accordance with it,
In all his affairs.
Even a quality equal to omniscience,
Without support, fades away.
A priceless gem,

analyzed: hemam nissāya sobhate  pabbe pabbe kamen ucchu
translated: Shines when supported by gold.🔽In every place, in every direction,
From the peak of the mountain range,
So too, a good friend is good,
The opposite is a bad person.
Therefore, it was said by the Sage,
Some worldly dhammas,
And likewise, the dhammas that lead to Nibbāna,

analyzed: santi lokuttara adhammā  kalyāṇamitta mā agamma
translated: Are supramundane dhammas.🔽All of them become
For all living beings,
Therefore, in good friends,
One should always show respect.

original: Yo ve kataññū katavediko dhiro,🔽Kalyāṇamitto daḷhabhattica hoti;
analyzed: yaḥ ve kataññū kata vedikaḥ dhiraḥ  kalyāṇa mittaḥ daḷha bhatti ca hoti
translated: The wise one who is grateful and thankful,🔽Who has good friends and is very faithful,
Who respectfully does what needs to be done for the suffering,
Such a one is called a true person.

original: Yassahi dhammaṃ puriso vijaññā,🔽Yecassa kaṅkhaṃ vinayanti santo;
analyzed: yassa hi dhammam purisaḥ  kaṅkham vinayanti santaḥ
translated: If a person knows the Dhamma🔽And the noble ones dispel his doubts,
He will be an island unto himself,🔽A refuge unto himself, with no other refuge.
The wise one should not delay in befriending him.
The Story of the Leader
A farmer, a merchant, a fisherman,
A monk with learning and virtue;
Among them, if one is of great birth,
The country too may be great.
If they are of weak birth,
The country too may be weak;
Therefore, even if the country is great,
The king should support those of great worth in the country.🔽If one cuts the unripe fruit

analyzed: mahā rukkhassa phalinaḥ  āmam chindati yaḥ phalam
translated: Of a large, fruiting tree,
One does not know its taste,
And its seed is destroyed.🔽If one rules a country
That is like a large, fruiting tree,
Unrighteously,
One does not know its taste,

analyzed: raṭṭhan ca api vinassati  mahā rukkhassa phalinaḥ
translated: And the country is destroyed.🔽If one cuts the ripe fruit
Of a large, fruiting tree,
He knows the taste of it,
But forgets the seed.
A king who rules the country
In accordance with the Dhamma,
Knows the taste of it,
But forgets the country.
A king who rules the country
Unrighteously,🔽The king is in conflict

analyzed: viruddhaḥ hoti khattiyaḥ  tathā iva nigame hiṃsam
translated: With all the people.
And those who are engaged🔽In buying and selling in the town,
In usury and in taxes,
He is in conflict with them.
In the great fields and in the cattle pens,
In the assembly, in the forest,
If the king oppresses the people,

analyzed: sa balena virujjhati  tathā iva isayaḥ hiṃso
translated: He is in conflict with them.🔽And if the king oppresses
The seers who are restrained and celibate,
The king who acts unrighteously
Is in conflict with the gods.
Not by another’s doing,🔽But by one’s own doing,

analyzed: mahā najjaḥ juvaka tā  issarena tathā raññā
translated: The great danger of youth,
The king’s oppression of the country.

analyzed: pāpam vā api hi puññam vā
translated: Whether it is evil or good,
Whatever one does,
The world does the same,
The wise one should know this.
The turtle and the fish,
And of the hens and cows,
As the one who supports her children,
So among mortals, the kings.
Those without a leader are destroyed,
Those with many leaders are destroyed,🔽Those with a weak leader are destroyed,
Those with a good leader are destroyed.
Where there are many leaders,
All are conceited with wisdom,
All desire greatness,
Their work is destroyed.
For the destruction and ruin,
The land is full of many leaders;
They bow down and are destroyed,
Like lotuses with seven stalks.
The unsatisfied ascetic is destroyed,

analyzed: santuṭṭhaḥ uca mahīpati  sa lajjā gaṇikā naṭṭhā
translated: The satisfied king is destroyed,🔽The ashamed prostitute is destroyed,
The shameless noblewoman is destroyed.
One should not go with the crowd,
When the work is accomplished, the fruit is equal;
If there is failure in the work,
The talkative one is killed there.
The one who studies and the ascetic,
The hero and the one with wounds,
The drunkard and the king on the street,
I do not believe in these.
One should know the messenger,
Even if relatives come in fear;
And in calamities, a friend,
And a wife in the loss of wealth.

analyzed: raṇā paccā gatam sūram  dhanam ca gharam āgatam
translated: The hero who returns from battle,🔽and the man who comes home with wealth,
and the old man who is well-behaved,
and the son who has passed his youth.

analyzed: saddhā pemesu santesu  na gaṇe māsakam satam
translated: One should honour these who are good,🔽even if they are one’s enemies;
one should honour these who are good,
even if they are one’s enemies.
The gift that tames the untamed,
the gift that is successful in all things,
through the gift of love and kind words,
they rise up and bow down.

analyzed: dānam sineha bhesajjam  maccheram dussanosadham  dānam yasas sabhosajjam
translated: The gift that is the medicine of love,🔽the gift that is the cure for stinginess,🔽the gift that is the medicine of fame,

analyzed: maccheram kappanosadham  dubbhikkhe anna dātam ca  subhikkhe ca hirañña dam
translated: the gift that is the cure for miserliness.🔽The gift of food in time of famine,🔽and the gift of gold in time of plenty,
the gift of safety in time of fear,
is much esteemed even in heaven.
A hundred eyes, a hundred ears,
the son of the leader always listens;
yet the wise man is still blind,
this is the nature of the leader.
Patience, watchfulness, standing firm,
sharing, and the time to give,
these are the qualities of the leader,
to be desired by one who seeks his welfare.🔽The humble man is despised,
and the very harsh man is hated;
knowing both these things,
One should practice the middle way.
One cannot be great with complete softness,
Nor with complete sharpness;
One should establish oneself in greatness,
Therefore one should practice both.
One should not serve one who is behind,🔽Nor one who is in front of the fire;
One should serve one’s master with all one’s being,
Without deceiving the other world.
One should not serve one who is harsh,
One should avoid that miser;
Then one should serve one who is generous,
One should serve one who is restrained after that;

original: Na sā rājā yo ajeyyaṃ jināti,
analyzed: na sā rājā yaḥ ajeyyam jināti
translated: That is not a king who conquers the unconquerable,
That is not a friend who conquers a friend;
That is not a wife who opposes her husband,

original: Na te vuttā ye nabharanti jiṇṇakaṃ.
translated: Those are not words that do not support the aged.

original: Na sā sabhā yattha nasanti santo,
analyzed: na sā sabhā yattha nasanti santaḥ
translated: That is not an assembly where the good are destroyed,

original: Na te santo ye navadanti dhammaṃ;
analyzed: na te santaḥ ye na vadanti dhammaṃ
translated: Those are not the good who do not proclaim the Dhamma;

original: Rāgañca dosañca pahāya mohaṃ,🔽Dhammaṃ bhaṇantāva bhavanti santo.
analyzed: rāgañca dosañca pahāya moham  dhammam bhaṇantā ava bhavanti santo
translated: Having abandoned passion, hatred, and delusion,🔽Those who speak the Dhamma are the good.
The protection of what is heard is constant application;
The duty of a family is the knowledge of a man;
The heedlessness of a king is the satisfaction of a debtor,
I know the protection of the lazy is never.

analyzed: namātarā vā api  bhagīniyā vicakkhaṇo  na vivitta āsane mante
translated: A mother, or even a daughter,🔽A sister, or a clever woman,🔽A woman who is not a stranger,
A woman who is skilled in deception.🔽The fickleness of lightning,
The sharpness of swords,
The swiftness of wind and fire,
Women imitate all these.
The appetite of women is double,🔽Their intelligence is a quarter,
Their exertion is sixfold,
Their passion is eightfold.
For each woman there are eight husbands,
Brave and strong,

analyzed: kareyya navame chandam  unnattā hi napūrati
translated: Who can give all kinds of sensual pleasures,🔽But in the ninth year, passion is aroused.
For they are not satisfied with one,
Seeing another's wealth,
Thinking of another's mind,
Who is dear to women?🔽Even if one with a thousand tongues
Lived for a hundred years,
One could not describe
The faults of women.
Fire, water, women, fools,
Snakes, and royal families,
Should be avoided from a distance,

analyzed: maccu pāṇa harān iti  itthīnam dujjanāḥ nañ ca
translated: For they take away life.🔽One should not trust women
Or those who are deceitful.
The disease of the lion, the king of beasts,
And the royal family of the River-king.
The sword is to be well-tested and well-thought-about,🔽The forest-fire, though it has been lit by oneself, is to be feared,
The young woman, though she is in one’s own hand, is to be guarded,
How much more so the young women of the forest-monasteries.
The undertaking of unsuitable work is a dispute,
The Saṅgha’s war with the great army,
The work of trust is always in carelessness,
These are the doors of death, say the wise.
A man might try to catch the wind with a net,
Or sprinkle the ocean with one hand,
Or make a sound with a single drum-skin,
He who would trust in carelessness.
Even if it is only one woman,
The Sage has said she is the worst,
Of quarrels the worst is a woman,🔽The worst supporter is a woman.

original: Yo naṃ bharati sabbadā,🔽Niccaṃ ātāpi ussuko;
analyzed: yaḥ nam bharati sabbadā  niccam ātāpi ussukaḥ
translated: He who always supports her,🔽Always being diligent and active,
The provider of all she desires,
Does not despise his wife.

analyzed: bhattāram  issā cārena rosaye  bhattu ca garu nosabbe
translated: Even if the husband is well,🔽She makes him angry through jealousy,🔽The wise one reveres her husband,
And all who are senior to him.
She is energetic, not idle,🔽She manages the domestic help,
She is pleasing and agreeable to her husband,
She protects the wealth he earns.

analyzed: evam vattati yā anārī  bhattu chanda vasā anugā
translated: A woman who behaves like this,🔽Who follows her husband’s wishes,
Will be reborn in a place that is pleasing,

analyzed: yattha sā upapajjati  kokilānam saraḥ rūpam
translated: Wherever she is reborn.🔽The voice of the cuckoo is beautiful,
The form of a woman is beautiful,
Knowledge is beautiful among the gods,
Patience is beautiful among ascetics.

analyzed: āneya kula jam pañño  virūpam api kaññakam
translated: A wise man should marry a girl

analyzed: surūpāya  vivāha aṃsa disam kare  visamhāmatam ādeyya
translated: From a good family, even if she is ugly,

analyzed: amajjamha apikañcanam  nicamhā api uttamā vijjā  rata nitthī pidu kulā  bālitthī makkhikātuṇḍam
translated: But he should not marry a beautiful girl🔽From a low family, even if she is beautiful.🔽A bad woman is like a bad gem,
A bad woman is like a bad flower,
A bad woman is like a bad fruit,🔽A bad woman is like a bad field.

analyzed: bālakkaḥ  vuddhitthī pallala udakam  āyu khaya karam niccam
translated: A bad woman is like a bad wife,🔽A bad woman is like a bad mother,🔽A bad woman is like a bad daughter,

analyzed: dadhi bhojanam  thiyaḥ seveyya naccantam  sādum bhuñjeyi anāhitam
translated: A bad woman is like a bad friend.🔽A bad woman is like a bad slave,🔽A bad woman is like a bad servant,
A bad woman is like a bad nurse,🔽A bad woman is like a bad relative.

original: Guruṃ māyāya nobhaje.🔽Ācāro kula mākhyāti,🔽Desa mākhyāti bhāsitaṃ;
analyzed: gurum māyāya na ubhaje  ācāraḥ kula mākhyāti  bhāsitam
translated: Do not deceive the teacher with deceit.🔽Do not advertise the family,🔽Do not advertise the country, the speech;
Do not advertise the origin, the love,
Do not advertise the body, the food.
Through the words give me,

analyzed: dehaṭṭhā pañca devatā  sajja niyanti dhī kitti
translated: The five deities in the body are ready;🔽The mind is ready for fame,
And also for shame, glory, and wisdom.
The word give me is suffering,
The word no is the same;

analyzed: vākyam dehi iti na atthi iti
translated: The words give me and no,
May they not be in any existence.

analyzed: bodhayanti na yācanti  dehi iti pacchimājanā
translated: They awaken and request,🔽Give me - the people of the future;
See the giving of goods,
May it not be like this.
The great one goes to the very small,
The virtuous one here to the non-virtuous;
By the state of being worthless to the worthless,
Like the elephant king to the stump.
Having made a great support,
The small one becomes great in existence;
Having reached the golden mountain,
The golden-winged birds.
For many who have spread out,
The state of unity is indeed difficult to attain;
The rope is twisted with grass,
By that even the elephant is bound.
Even one who is able without a companion,
What can he do in the fire?
The fire that is settled in the wind,
It is self-pacified.
The ability to bear the heat of the sun’s rays
is not due to the color of the skin;
The ability to bear the rod of punishment

analyzed: na bhacca jo  thī saṃsagge kutosuddhaḥ  maṃsa bhakkhe kutas udayā
translated: is not due to the color of the skin.🔽How can there be purity in association with a woman?

analyzed: surā pāṇe kutosaccam  pa kodhamhi kutotapo  thīyā guyham
translated: How can there be rise in one who eats meat?🔽How can there be truth in drinking alcohol?🔽How can there be austerity in anger?
A wise man should not consult🔽with a woman or an enemy.
One who associates with a bad person
is a man with a heart of flesh.
Secret matters
are revealed by a man.
Out of fear of a split in the council,
he endures as if a slave.

analyzed: vahe amitta khandhena  yāva kāle anāgate
translated: Until the time comes,🔽he should carry the load of his enemy.
But when that time comes,
he should break the pot on the flower.🔽Having gone to the field of the wicked,

original: Khalaṃ sālaṃ pasuṃ khettaṃ,🔽Gantvācassa abhikkhaṇaṃ;🔽Mitaṃ dhaññaṃ nidhāpeyya,
analyzed: khalam sālam pasum khettam  gantvā acassa abhikkhaṇam  mitam dhaññam nidhāpeyya
translated: the tree, the animal, and the field,🔽he should store a measured amount of grain,
and cook a measured amount in the house.

original: Kodhaṃ lobhaṃ madaṃ mānaṃ,🔽Tandiṃ missaṃ pamattakaṃ;🔽Soṇṭhaṃniddhālukaṃ makkhaṃ,
analyzed: kodham lobham madam mānam  tandim missam pamattakam  makkham
translated: Anger, greed, conceit, pride,🔽sloth, confusion, negligence,🔽cunning, deceit, hypocrisy,
and stinginess—the wise one should abandon these.
Anger arisen within,
The angry man destroys himself,
As the flame burns the flower-bush.
If anger arises,
One should recollect the simile of the saw;
If craving arises,

original: Puttamaṃsūpamaṃ sare.🔽Guṇa maddhisamaṃ makkhe,🔽Parena kalahe sati;
analyzed: putta maṃsu upamam sare  guṇa maddhi samam makkhe  parena kalahe sati
translated: One should recollect the simile of the flesh of one’s own son.🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;

original: Addhisamaṃ pakāseti,🔽Aṇumattaṃvavajjakaṃ.🔽Tasseva tena pāpīyo,🔽Yo kuddhaṃ paṭikujjhati;
analyzed: addhi samam pakāsa iti  aṇumattam vavajjakam  tassa iva tena pāpīyaḥ  yaḥ kuddham paṭikujjhati
translated: If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;
If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;
If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;

analyzed: rāhu vijjā sasaṅkassa  tapodhana hutāsano  pamādaḥ jāyate madā  pamādā jāyate khayo
translated: If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;
If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;

original: Madaṃ kiṃ najahe budho.🔽Namanti phalinorukkhā,🔽Namanti vibudhājanā;
analyzed: madam kim najahe budho  namanti  namanti
translated: If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;
If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;

analyzed: bhijjatā iva nanamanti  ṭhāne mā ukāsam
translated: If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;

analyzed: dade vuddha apacāyikaḥ  nanu tālaḥ ajīvaḥ api
translated: If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;🔽If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;
If one is reviled, one should think of one’s own faults;

analyzed: garu kātabba posesu  nicca vuttim karoti yaḥ
translated: He who always does what should be done for those who should be respected,
He who abandons what should not be done,

analyzed: uttamatte patiṭṭhati  yattha posam na jānanti
translated: He stands supreme.
Where they do not know the guest by birth or by training,

original: Na tattha mānaṃ kariyā,🔽Vasa maññātakejane.🔽Aññātavāsaṃ vasatā,
analyzed: na tattha mānam kariyā  vasa maññātakejane  aññāta vāsam vasatā
translated: There one should not make a display of pride,🔽But live among those who are ignorant of one’s true self.🔽Even though one lives in a place unknown to others,
Even though one lives like one who has no knowledge,🔽The wise one should endure it,
Even if one is a slave, one should be self-controlled.
In the acquisition of wealth and grain,
And likewise in the pursuit of knowledge,
In the sending of messengers and in business,

original: Cattalajjo sadā bhave.🔽Nahi koci kate kicce,
analyzed: sadā bhave  nahi kaḥ ci kate kicce
translated: One should always have four kinds of shame.🔽For no one looks for the doer
When a deed has been done,
Therefore all one’s actions
Should be done with a remainder.
The remainder of a debt, the remainder of a fire,
The remainder of enemies, these three
Increase again and again,
Therefore one should not leave a remainder.
There is no wealth equal to knowledge,
There is no enemy like hatred,
There is no love like the love of oneself,
There is no strength greater than patience.
One becomes fortunate by oneself,

analyzed: alakkhīcā api attanā  nahi lakkhī a lakkhī ca
translated: And unfortunate by oneself;🔽For fortune and misfortune
Are not made by another.
The king’s own income and expenditure,
he himself should know what is done and what not done;
He himself should be the one to give up the world,
what is done and what is not done.
He should help even an enemy with what is beneficial,
the enemy should be freed by the one who is wise;
The foot-print of the elephant is the best,
the thorn is removed by the thorn.
He should serve one who serves him, he should honour one who honours him,
he should do a service for one who does a service for him;
He should not do a favour for one who does not want a favour,
he should not associate with one who does not want to associate.
He should abandon one who abandons him, he should make him new,
he should not associate with one who is not of a like mind;
The bee, having thought the tree is without flowers,
would look for another, the great world.
